title: Indigenous food systems biocultural heritage and the SDGs (session four)

tasks.task: Conducting interdisciplinary research on Indigenous food systems and biocultural heritage involves several key subtasks:
subtasks: Mapping territory, collecting seeds and botanical specimens, conducting ethnobotanical interviews, compiling data into databases or manuals, training community members in traditional practices, participating in community events, and collaborating across disciplines. The primary focus is on cultural heritage preservation and promoting sustainable agricultural practices through collaborative, Indigenous-led research methodologies. PHYSICAL TASKS FOR EVERYDAY LIVING: Conducting field surveys, processing traditional foods, creating visual maps and diagrams, managing seed banks, organizing community gatherings, and engaging in ongoing data analysis and publication. TASK DECLARATIONS: MAINTASK: Conducting interdisciplinary research on Indigenous food systems; SUBTASKS: Ethnobotanical approaches, participatory action research, ethnobotanical documentation, interdisciplinary research methods, conservation and genetic diversity, revitalizing traditional recipes, respecting Indigenous research methods, integrating climate resilience, promoting Indigenous knowledge systems, policy engagement. PHYSICAL TASKS: Mapping territory, collecting specimens, gathering oral histories, creating visual representations, coordinating community events, participating in traditional practices, communicating research findings. tasks.task: Conduct Academic and Research-Based Tasks to Preserve and Study Indigenous Food Systems**

To effectively document and protect Indigenous Food Systems and biocultural heritage, interdisciplinary research methods such as ethnobotany, participatory action research, and archaeological analysis are essential. Key subtasks include collecting traditional knowledge, engaging communities in research, conservation, revitalizing traditional practices, and sharing findings. This approach ensures that food systems remain resilient and culturally relevant in the face of change. TASKS: Conduct ethnobotanical surveys, engage communities in participatory research, conserve endangered crops, revitalize traditional recipes, apply interdisciplinary methods, and acknowledge Indigenous knowledge contributors. These tasks collectively support the preservation and promotion of Indigenous Food Systems. Physical tasks involve data collection, community engagement, knowledge transfer, and policy advocacy. By integrating traditional and modern methodologies, these research efforts aim to reinforce cultural practices and ecological sustainability.
Conduct academic research and community engagement to preserve Indigenous food systems through ethnobotany, participatory approaches, interdisciplinary methods, and conservation efforts.
